image.altText: A man with tattoos on his shoulders sits in a bath and looks into the camera.

props.synopsis: Clearance divers have among the highest suicide rates of all defence personnel. An ABC investigation has spoken to more than a dozen former divers experiencing a cluster of symptoms they believe is connected to blast exposure.

title.children: These men knew signing up to the Navy would be risky. The toll on their brains wasn't revealed until years later

image.altText: Ilya Fomin stands near a front door

props.synopsis: Despite consulting with bank staff before transferring his life savings, Ilya Fomin lost $280,000 to scammers. His bank hasn't accepted any responsibility — new scam laws may change that.

title.children: Ilya's life savings were stolen when he transferred $280K from NAB to Commonwealth Bank. Both banks and his law firm say it's not their fault

image.altText: Trump and Harris shake hands on a blue stage carpeted with a lectern in front of them

props.synopsis: Donald Trump rules out a third presidential debate before the November 5 election, with Kamala Harris saying "we owe it to the voters".

title.children: Donald Trump rules out another debate with Kamala Harris

image.altText: A person's hands are illuminated by the pale glow of a computer screen, as they type in a dark room.

props.synopsis: The internet's capacity to amplify lies, hatred and malicious behaviour has been well demonstrated in the past year, exposing what the government says is a regulation gap it wants to close.

title.children: How do you police speech online? The government has ventured an answer

image.altText: Ukrainian servicemen ride a military vehicle.

props.synopsis: Moscow's forces begin a counteroffensive in the Kursk region, claiming to have recaptured 10 settlements seized by Ukrainian forces in a surprise incursion into western Russia last month.

title.children: 'They will outnumber them': Russia begins counter-offensive in Kursk

props.synopsis: Every time you pick up your phone, you have to decide what's true and what's fake. And it's getting harder.

title.children: Most Australians struggle to spot what's real and what's fake. Here's some help

image.altText: A close up of Yvonne Buters wearing a black shirt with white flowers on it, looking directly into the camera.

props.synopsis: Stronger protections for older Australians and hefty fines for providers who breach standards are part of the federal government's sweeping changes to the aged care sector.

title.children: Woman who lost both parents in aged care hopes new laws will hold providers accountable

image.altText: main pic of the two

props.synopsis: The Miss Universe Fiji voting drama has seen accusations of racism, vote-rigging, conflicts of interest and "conspiracy theories". But in Fiji, the saga is triggering a different kind of response: one of embarrassment and anger.

title.children: Miss Universe Fiji scandal erupts as 'runner up' claims she's the winner two weeks after the event

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers, Minister for Aged Care Anika Wells and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: This week saw a huge flurry of government activity — it's as if the government looked up at the clock and saw time was rapidly getting away from it. But what loomed largest was tying down the aged care deal.

title.children: Why Dutton backed Albanese's aged care reforms

image.altText: debris underneath an archway with people standing around.

props.synopsis: An air strike on a school in central Gaza killed six humanitarian workers. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: 'Endless and senseless killing': What we know about the Israeli air strike that killed six UN workers

image.altText: A woman sleeps with a quilt on against a blue backdrop

props.synopsis: Sleep. It unites yet perplexes us all … so let's get some answers! Follow our live Q&A sleep blog and tap into the minds of some of the country's best sleep scientists.

title.children: Want to improve your sleep? Ask our experts anything

image.altText: A man in a blue jacket and light pants stands bathed in light at the end of a black tunnel underground.

props.synopsis: A strange signal that shook the planet in September last year has been traced back to a tsunami from a melting glacier in the Arctic. And it may happen again.

title.children: A mysterious underground signal rippled around the world for nine days. Now we know why

image.altText: A group of little girls smile through a barred window

props.synopsis: In the shadow of a garbage tip lies a multi-generational haven for women and girls in Phnom Penh. Free from the world of men, they study, work and support each other.

title.children: 'We are girls, and we live with only girls': Come inside Cambodia's women-only village

image.altText: A rainbow flag

props.synopsis: The Western Australian government says it "won't have time" to pass a ban on gay conversion therapy before next year's state election, despite a promise made two years ago.

title.children: Western Australia pushes back plan to ban gay conversion therapy

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is set to open higher this morning following Wall Street, where positive economic data firmed expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut next week in the US. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Australian sharemarket to open higher, EU cuts rates

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Banking lobby group welcomes scam legislation
Spotlight on scams: banks, telcos, tech giants to face fines

image.altText: An aerial shot, rendered, showing the roofs of three buildings and a courtyard connecting them

props.synopsis: Established suburbs are often left out of the housing crisis discussion, but an architecture expert has an innovative idea that could be part of the solution.

title.children: Why older, leafy suburbs could be a key piece of the puzzle in solving Australia's housing crisis

image.altText: A vehicle with camouflage colours.

props.synopsis: Outside police and protesters are battling on the streets. But inside, the battle is for business. Some attendees say the protesters went too far.

title.children: 'What about Ukraine?' Exhibitor at Land Forces Expo says protesters only worried about Palestine

image.altText: GettyImages-455768000

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide and Hawthorn will meet for just the third time in a finals clash in Friday night's semifinal. If the previous two meetings are anything to go by, fans are in for an absolute treat.

title.children: A concussed hero and a dynasty that almost wasn't — a look at Port and Hawthorn's thrilling finals history

image.altText: Bailey Smith

props.synopsis: Trade requests are far from rare in the AFL, but Bailey Smith's connection to a Geelong fashion company has pundits questioning whether clubs are on a level playing field.

title.children: Fashion deals and Cats connections — why this AFL star's trade request has raised eyebrows in footy circles

props.synopsis: A lawyer for sexual abuse survivor Adam Kneale says he is searching for more victims of club volunteer Graeme Hobbs, as the club appeals against a payout.

title.children: Western Bulldogs sexual abuse payout faces appeal as new claim emerges against the club

image.altText: the outside of a building

props.synopsis: A casino dealer employed by The Star casino in Sydney is one of two people accused of rigging multiple games of roulette last year, earning more than $25,000 in the process.

title.children: Casino dealer charged over rigging roulette games at The Star Sydney

image.altText: A man sits with his hand on his head.

props.synopsis: Prosecutor Nicole Blumberg did not specify the new charges Harvey Weinstein faces during a hearing before Judge Curtis Farber in New York state court in Manhattan.

title.children: Harvey Weinstein charged in New York with additional crimes

image.altText: A composite photo

props.synopsis: It's time to see if you've been paying attention to the news this week!

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A Taylor Swift endorsement, political deepfakes, and buying up gold

image.altText: Close up of woman's face as she looks upward and reflects on the environment around her

props.synopsis: At the heart of the Tarkine is Australia's largest tract of cool temperate rainforest, but parts of this awe-inspiring wilderness remain unprotected from native tree logging.

title.children: Marta Dusseldorp ventures into the heart of Tasmania's 'spectacular' ancient rainforest

image.altText: An astronaut in silhouette, against a crescent of the Earth, half out of spacecraft.

props.synopsis: A billionaire stepped out for the first private spacewalk Thursday, teaming up with SpaceX on the daring endeavour hundreds of miles above Earth.

title.children: Billionaire steps out of SpaceX capsule for first private spacewalk

image.altText: An Asian man with black hair and glasses, wearing a blue shirt and white t-shirt, looks unsmiling at the camera

props.synopsis: Melbourne writer André Dao, who penned a genre-defying account of his grandfather's remarkable life, is one of six winners at the 2024 Prime Minister's Literary Awards.

title.children: André's grandfather was a political prisoner for 10 years. The novel about his life has just won $80,000

image.altText: A colourful pigeon looking at the camera.

props.synopsis: The annual Ig Nobel awards celebrates a slew of bizarre research that makes you laugh, and then makes you think. These are some of this year's winners.

title.children: WWII bird-guided missile research code-named 'Project Pigeon' wins quirky award

image.altText: A Yazidi man and his wife stand on the beach smiling, holding two small children.

props.synopsis: Yazidis living in Australia are petitioning to be recognised in the 2026 census to help ensure they are considered in future policy making and their unique culture is not lost.

title.children: This ancient religion is growing fast in Australia, but it isn't included in the census

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo, known as Lawyer X, wearing a leopard print top stares out a window

props.synopsis: A controversial bill designed to limit civil claims relating to the Lawyer X scandal has passed Victoria's upper house, after the government struck a last-minute deal to push the legislation through.

title.children: Lawyer X bill limiting civil compensation to $1 million passes Victorian upper house

image.altText: A scene from the movie Beetlejuice Beetlejuice with Michael Keaton in character as a ghoul in striped suit, weird creature in bg

props.synopsis: The long-awaited sequel to Tim Burton's classic '80s ghostly comedy reveals the old spirit of Beetlejuice is hard to summon — but there is still gooey and gory fun to be had.

title.children: It looks like Beetlejuice, it sounds like Beetlejuice, but can the sequel live up to the original?

image.altText: A stocky man in sunglasses walks down a flight of stairs.

props.synopsis: A man who restrained three young children in WA's north after he found them swimming in his pool has faced trial, with his defence lawyer arguing he is "a victim of crime".

title.children: Broome man who cable-tied children's hands made 'lawful' citizen's arrest, court hears

image.altText: Adam Bray, right, and Zach Bray who died in the hunter bus crash of June 11, 2023

props.synopsis: Adam Bray, who lost his son Zach in the crash, says the class action will target Transport for NSW for providing "very poor infrastructure". It comes after the bus driver was sentenced to 32 years' jail.

title.children: Father of Hunter Valley bus crash victim to launch class action against Transport for NSW

image.altText: Jon Bon Jovi Nashville bridge video still

props.synopsis: Jon Bon Jovi has helped to persuade a woman standing on the ledge of a pedestrian bridge in Nashville to come back over the railing to safety.

title.children: Jon Bon Jovi helps talk woman down from ledge on Nashville bridge
